title: Derby Skater Discovers Community Through Adversity
text:
Search Derby Skater Discovers Community Through Adversity Posted by jforbis on February 22, 2017 in Denver , Denver Front , Denver Sports , Lifestyles | 43 Views | Leave a response 
Adversity is something that everyone will face at some point, the effort you 
make to overcome the struggles is what will define you. Lindsay Gypin, a roller derby 
skater, knows all too well about the challenges that life can throw your way through 
unexpected twists and turns. 

Lindsay Gypin began her life on the track seven years ago, originally skating with a roller 
derby team in Castle Rock, Colorado. Like many skaters around that time, Lindsay drew 
inspiration from the movie Whip It and decided to give roller derby a try. She fell in love 
with the sport, the physical contact, and the competitive nature that the sport provides. 
As a fan of Star Wars and at the suggestion of her husband at the time, she went by the 
alter ego Menace – based on the phantom menace from Star Wars. 

While Lindsay may have started in roller derby as a hobby, she found the community 
she needed when the adversity hit. Everyone faces hurdles, unfortunately for Lindsay, 
those struggles piled up at the same time. In a very short period last year, Lindsay went 
through a divorce, had to sell her home and lost her job – her life was in a lot of upheavals. 
Through the struggles, the one constant in her life was roller derby – it was the thing 
she could turn to when the chips were down. 

Lindsay decided to get her life back on track she needed to focus on herself – she 
created goals to work toward on the track, and off-track, she moved north from Castle 
Rock to Denver, joined Denver Roller Derby (DRD) permanently and went back to school to get 
her masters in library sciences. Now Lindsay has a renewed focus in life, and she 
credits roller derby for providing that support to help her right her life. “Roller Derby 
served as a positive influence on my life. It taught me perseverance and allowed me to 
take charge of transforming my life for the better.” Lindsay Gypin skating with Denver Roller Derby during the Besterns tournament in 2016. Photo courtesy of Joel Glitner. 
Roller derby is more than just a hobby or a sport; it’s a community of like-minded 
individuals who look out for the well-being of others and provides support when people 
face challenges. Derby is a community that lifts people up and allows people to succeed 
on and off the track. Off the track, she may be a librarian, but on the track her presence, 
focus and athletic drive is anything but quiet. 

Lindsay plays on the Shotgun Betties of the home teams with Denver Roller Derby and 
is also a member of DRD’s travel team, Mile High Club. 

On Sat., Feb. 25, watch Menace and the Shotgun Betties take on the Green Barrettes in 
the second half of a doubleheader. Be sure to get there for the first bout starting at 6 
p.m. featuring the Bad Apples and last year’s champions – the Orange Crushers in the 
second game of the season. Doors for the bout will open at 5 p.m. at the Glitterdome 
located at 3600 Wynkoop Street in RiNo. Tickets are $12 with kids 12, and under free, 
go to www.denverrollerderby.org/tickets to purchase tickets for the game.
